race.name: Salty Lizard
race.tagline: Moondust and volcanic terrain through the Silver Island Mountains near Wendover, Utah.

terrain.surface: Gravel roads through Utah desert. Moderate elevation with desert scenery.

gravel_god_rating.score_note: Regional UT event. Desert terrain with remote location, high altitude, and small local field.

biased_opinion.summary: Salty Lizard is a regional event in Utah—desert terrain with moderate elevation and high altitude. The Utah desert is unique, but the small local field, remote location, and limited organization keep it in Tier 4.
biased_opinion.bottom_line: A solid regional UT desert gravel race. Worth it for UT/Mountain West riders seeking desert experience. Not worth traveling far for.

final_verdict.should_you_race: If you're local to UT and want desert experience—yes. If you're traveling—skip it.
final_verdict.alternatives: For better UT races: Wasatch All-Road, Dirty Dino.

logistics.lodging_strategy: Wendover has limited lodging. Plan ahead.
logistics.food: Wendover has limited dining. Stock nutrition.
logistics.camping: camping experience for vans and tents

course_description.signature_challenge: Utah desert terrain at high altitude.

non_negotiables.why: Utah desert conditions require specific preparation.
Limited aid stations and remote location require self-sufficiency.

marketplace_variables.race_hook_detail: Regional event with desert terrain and high altitude.

logistics.explanation: Start atmosphere at Historic Wendover Airfield Museum includes 'the smell of bacon hung in the air over the camping area and the soft hiss of aerosol lubricants' creating race-day buzz. Course distances remain inconsistent between editions—husterk raced 104 miles with 4300ft in 2022 versus current 50-mile listings. BikeReg registration available but production inconsistencies persist despite race director offering guest rooms to visiting riders. As Pre-Race Atmosphere [COMPETITIVE source] puts it: "The Historic Wendover Airfield Museum buzzed as riders bombed down from hotels and emptied out of cars newly arrived from the Wasatch Front."

length.explanation: Husterk felt 'great at the 50-mile mark' but warned 'it's one thing to feel great at the 50-mile mark. It is an entirely different thing to still feel that well after 100+ miles.' Course distance confusion continues with his 2022 edition measuring 104 miles while current listings show 50 miles, suggesting significant route changes that complicate training preparation. More compact than Grinduro.

technicality.explanation: Aria Blvd opening descent crashes riders through 'deep pea gravel, sand, bedrock, larger gravel, more sand, hardpack' where 'riders of all abilities were taken out by the twisting descent.' Silver Island Pass features traditionally loose sections with deep sand traps, while the finishing route alternates 'between hardpack and deep sand and pea gravel' with a final pass delivering 'a wave-like berm of soft gravel.' Less technical than The Mid South. As Bobby Kennedy puts it: "The climb arched suddenly upward to the bench at mile 81, climbing an 'unswitchbacked' dirt bike trail sprinkled with golf ball-sized stones that had been the fastest descent in previous editions of t..."

elevation.explanation: Bobby Kennedy confirms backend-loaded climbing with the hardest section after mile 81 where 'the climb arched suddenly upward to the bench' on an 'unswitchbacked dirt bike trail sprinkled with golf ball-sized stones.' husterk brought mountain bike gearing specifically for 'a steep climb late in the race' on the 2022 edition with 4300 feet over 104 miles through Silver Island Mountains backcountry. Less climbing than The Mid South. As Bobby Kennedy puts it: "The climb arched suddenly upward to the bench at mile 81, climbing an 'unswitchbacked' dirt bike trail sprinkled with golf ball-sized stones that had been the fastest descent in previous editions of t..."

climate.explanation: April date change eliminated desert heat issues with Bobby Kennedy noting October 2022 had 'rain the week before that knocked down the dust and temps hovered around livable.' The 2024 race delivered 'close to perfect temperatures, overcast skies and plenty of moondust' despite potential to be 'a salty sauna out there' in the Silver Island Mountains desert environment. More weather exposure than Belgian Waffle Ride San Diego. As Bobby Kennedy puts it: "It was a suspiciously glorious day in Wendover as riders lined up at the Wendover Airfield Museum for the start. Rain the week before had knocked down the dust and the temps hovered around livable."

altitude.explanation: Wendover sits around 4200 feet elevation in the Silver Island Mountains desert terrain. husterk's extensive first-race preparation covering bike setup, nutrition strategy, and detailed pacing plans never mentioned altitude as a limiting factor despite racing over 100 miles through the backcountry, suggesting manageable impact for most riders at this elevation. Modest altitude compared to Belgian Waffle Ride San Diego.

adventure.explanation: Racing delivers what riders call 'riding on the moon…er the Silver Island Mountains north of Wendover, Utah is enchanting' through volcanic terrain and moondust. husterk found 'the second half of the race was where things really started to become challenging; both physically and mentally' crossing Silver Island Pass twice through remote backcountry with deep sand sections and backend-loaded climbing. As Location Benefits [UNKNOWN source] puts it: "Welcome to Wendover, a salty land that's full of adventure! It's less than 2 hours to get here from Salt Lake City..."

prestige.explanation: Husterk used this as 'my first official gravel race' on a mountain bike, while race director John Hernandez tells riders to 'come out, bring whatever bike I have, and have some fun riding in the desert!' The welcoming grassroots approach attracts beginners learning gravel basics rather than competitive talent seeking national recognition or pro-level competition.

race_quality.explanation: Breanne Harward brings professional racing experience promising riders 'will be safe, know where they are on course' with 'great after party' execution from her elite background. husterk called his first race 'amazing' but course distances shifting dramatically between 50-104 miles across editions shows production inconsistencies despite organizers' experience and good intentions for rider safety.

experience.explanation: Finish line features race director John Hernandez 'and a growing welcoming party sat tailgating the finish line. And, most importantly, free fry bread.' Start atmosphere includes camping with bacon smells and 'the soft hiss of aerosol lubricants' creating grassroots production at Historic Wendover Airfield Museum with post-race casino entertainment options in border town Wendover.

community.explanation: Organizers 'pride ourselves on being a welcoming and inclusive ride for whoever you are and however fast you are, mostly because the people who run the race are themselves pretty slow and not very pleasant.' The grassroots atmosphere includes camping areas, post-race tailgating with free fry bread, and race director hospitality offering guest rooms three miles from start to visiting riders.

field_depth.explanation: With a field of 50-100 riders, husterk dominates race coverage as a recreational rider on mountain bike 'keeping up with other riders that I expected would drop me early in the race.' Elite coverage focuses on Bobby Kennedy's tactical analysis and Bri Hoopes' aid station strategy rather than competitive depth, indicating limited talent pool at this remote desert location despite Utah Gravel Series affiliation. Thinner field than Ouray Gravel Grinder. As Bobby Kennedy puts it: "The climb arched suddenly upward to the bench at mile 81, climbing an 'unswitchbacked' dirt bike trail sprinkled with golf ball-sized stones that had been the fastest descent in previous editions of t..."

value.explanation: Silver Island Mountains backcountry adventure through volcanic moondust terrain offers solid value with free fry bread, camping options, and unique desert racing experience. The 'bring whatever bike' grassroots approach keeps barriers low while delivering what husterk called an 'amazing' first gravel experience through terrain riders describe as 'riding on the moon' with post-race Wendover entertainment.

expenses.explanation: Registration runs $70-90. Wendover border town location offers casino lodging without resort pricing and 'less than 2 hours to get here from Salt Lake City' for regional accessibility. Race director hospitality includes offering visiting riders guest rooms three miles from start, while camping options and casual 'bring whatever bike' atmosphere keep logistics affordable for the grassroots crowd seeking desert adventure. Similar expense level to Belgian Waffle Ride San Diego.

citations.label: velo.outsideonline.com: The Grind A Not Quite Farewell To Gravel

key_takeaways: Race history (founded year, founder if known): First race in Utah Gravel Series on August 24, 2024; organizer Breanne Harward (possibly founder)

primary.name: Specialized Pathfinder Pro
primary.why: Fast center, grippy edges. The modern all-rounder benchmark.

primary.name: Panaracer GravelKing SK
primary.why: Affordable all-rounder. Light knobs add grip without killing speed.

primary.name: Vittoria Terreno Mix
primary.why: Graphene versatility. Mixed-terrain grip with reasonable rolling speed.

front_rear_split.rationale: Faster front for reduced rolling resistance on straights, grippier rear for traction on loose climbs and corners

videos.title: Salty Lizard 100 // Gravel Race // Wendover, UT
videos.description:
Experience Keith's first-ever gravel race at the Salty Lizard 100 in Wendover, NV. This race was Keith's first attempt at riding a true century (100+ miles with over 4000ft of climbing!). Will he make it to the end? You'll have to watch to find out.

Filmed on October 8, 2022

#gravel #gravelracing #gravelbike #gravelbikes #gravelroad #gravelroads #saltylizard #wendover #bikeracing #bikerace #gopro #goprohero10 #goprohero10black #cycling #cyclinglife

to this descent down silver Island pass

myself pretty hard to try to keep up

they were moving pretty quick and I had

this climb took us up to Aid Station 2
which was a water only aid station but
man I really needed it I needed a bottle

after leaving the Aid Station I

after leaving the Aid Station I got some

back off into the desert and this is

eventually I rolled up on the first of

felt like forever it was a low angle

but it kept having these false Flats
where you would think you got up to the

like I felt like I killed it going up
which I was shocked I was waiting all

I felt like I just really killed it

was actually telling me was that the

that I could recover even further on the

pedaly section back into town
this section was a lot of fun it was
kind of flowy and fast had some chunky
spots some deep sand kind of kept you
under toes a little bit but it was all
in all like a good kind of recovery spot
after that big climb and I knew there
was going to be quite a bit of downhill
coming
I finally started on The Descent down to
the final aid station this was kind of
my last chance to decide what I needed

grab some food if I needed to switch

whatever it might be so my brain was
kind of racing at this point like what

go how much harder is this gonna this

know can I get by with just a real quick
stop here do I need to stop longer and I
finally decided as I hit the pavement
that I'm going to make this one quick I
felt like I was moving pretty quick it's
up to this point and I wanted to keep my
my speed up and my time down so I

pavement was short-lived and we quickly

thinking to myself like uh where's
Wendover and how much further do we have

but like this was just the late race
brain I guess I was getting a little

wind over when I got to this final aid
station so Wendover was back east of me

yeah I hit this spot here so this was
like six inches of this super fine Munda
silt stuff
it was definitely hike a bike for me you
could see a few people made it through
they must have hit it really fast to get
up that there were a couple spots like
that but that one was really bad
but after I got through that I continued
pedaling on out into the desert and
eventually started wrapping around back
towards Wendover and I could see it way
off in the distance so it just kind of
gave me that like I can make it like
I've made it this far I'm gonna make it
to the end
I had another short little hike a bike
section here there are probably about
five or six of these throughout the
course this one was super steep and as I
was climbing this I felt a little twinge
in my calves and thought Oh that feels

last part you know I was very excited
but I guess kept pressing on was hoping

and then I finally made it to this

we were going to actually get to do it
or not but it's super cool it's all

the desert Trails turned into this Old

know take some pressure off your hands
and your in your butt so it's nice to

we are I can see part of the town like I
I can mentally see the finish and I am

I started pushing harder and harder and
harder and I could feel those cramps

extra get a little sugar in me I was

you rode a hundred mile race and you did

videos.curation_reason: First-person race recap with detailed course breakdown and specific terrain descriptions from a beginner's perspective.

videos.title: Salty Lizard Gravel Race Highlights 2021
videos.description:
Wide-open vistas and long, endless dirt roads as they weave through the beautiful desert landscape.
This years race was one to remember as riders faced ferocious winds, loose gravel, sticky mud and much cooler temps than normal.

videos.title: Salty Lizard 100 Gravel Race  year four,  Oct  14, 2023
videos.description: I had the idea to start  this gravel race 5  years ago in my hometown of Wendover as it has amazing endless dirt roads. Together with Bobby and Becky we put on the race for the first time in 2020.  This is the 4th year for the Salty Lizard gravel race.   I no longer live in Wendover  but go out to visit my brother and always bring my gravel bike.  I love bringing folks out to ride with me as they are always amazed at all the seemingly endless gravel roads and wide open spaces.   I really love the Wendover desert.  Plus you can ride your gravel bike out there, typically, year round.  Thanks to  Ben who joined me on my ride.  We both live in Cache Valley and are members of the Logan Race Club.  We had a great road riding season doing many fast Tuesday Night rides and weekend  road centuries together.  This was fitting to do another century  with him this time on gravel.

videos.title: Wendover Salty Lizard 100K+ Gravel Grinder 4-13-19
videos.description: 1st Annual "Wendover Salty Lizard 100K+ Gravel Grinder"on Utah Nevada border.  A free event.  14 friends drove out (most from Cache Valley, 2 from Park City)  to spend a beautiful day riding in the desert. I set up a course in my old hometown of Wendover, with the first loop riding west in Nevada, including the Dead Cow Loop, (a cow had died on this loop years ago now  leaving just a scattering of bones).  This loop a bit more rocky and loose and up and down.  Then connecting into a pretty smooth dirt road, slightly downhill, I call the Pilot Peak Loop road as you ride toward 10,000 ft Pilot Peak that pierces the sky in the distance.  We will connecting back into the Dead Cow loop and back to our lunch spot at Leppy's trails   After lunch we rode East into Utah around the first portion of the Silver Island Mountains on the Silver Island Loop road.  The day of, my niece, Karen, who set up our lunch, suggested the lunch spot  be at Leppy's trail park for convenience.  That was a great suggestion but added another 10-miles to the ride, 72 miles if you rode the entire two loops with 5,500+ feet of climbing. Well worth it. Some rode enough to get  their 100K. The riders came from Northern Utah  the land of Ice and Snow our longest ride of the year.  As you can see a combination of mountain and gravel bikes were rode.  On the Dead Cow loop mountain bikes worked better but on the Pilot Peak and Silver Island loop gravel bike rolled great. We topped off the event with dinner at the Salt Flats Cafe, serving delicious Mexican food.  Mucho fun day.  Thanks to all the that participated.

videos.title: Salty Lizard 100  Race Oct. 3,  2020 - HD 1080p
videos.description: The first Salty Lizard 100-mile gravel race in Wendover, UT/NV put on by Salty and Stupid Cycling.  There were 3 categories, 100, 65, & 45 miles.  This video highlights the 100-mile racer &, Boyd Cycles sponsored Tinker Juarez. What an honor to have this cycling legend ride the Salty Lizard. Tinker will start 8 minutes behind the leaders and will make up that time in the first 35 miles and be on a solo chase of Tanner Visnick, a pro mountain bike racer. Tanner broke away at 15 miles on a climb and will solo in for an amazing victor in 5 hours and 39 minutes.   Unfortunately for Tinker, on a 36-mile loop around the Silver Island mountains, he took a wrong road and lost valuable time.  He will still finish 4th, what an amazing athlete as he is nearing 60 years old.  Mya Dixon, a 16-year racer on the Reno Devo team out of Reno, NV, will crush it beating many of the men to win the small field of women 100-mile racer, in 6 hrs 53 minutes.  Thanks to Reno Devo race team for bringing so many of their young talented cyclists.   John Croom, a national champion track cyclist, will have a mechanical and not finish, glad to have him there too. Jeff Sumsion and Benjamin Fichialos entered the Stupid Lizard category, riding the 220-mile Stupid Pony gravel race from Eagle Mtn, UT on the Pony Express trail, on Friday. It finished at the Historic Wendover airfield.  Those two then got up to race the Salty Lizard 100 Saturday morning.  Both finished the 320 mile 2-day event, outstanding.   Thanks to all participants that came and rode/raced the first Salty Lizard Gravel event.  Watch for the 2nd Salty Lizard video which will highlight the 65- & 45-mile participants.

quotes.text: It didn't take long to hit the first downhill section and this was fast it was loose and rough and bumpy and I was watching these guys on gravel bikes slide out in front of me there's a couple of photographers catching people coming through here which made me think this is probably a rough little section.

The race took us out through the silver Island Scenic back way and this was spectacular like it is so beautiful out there especially if you love rocks and mountains and you can see the mountains on your left and the Salt Flats on your right is just incredible.

key_challenges.name: Huge Road climb out of town
key_challenges.description: Short but very steep climb that leads out of town to first taste of gravel

key_challenges.name: First downhill section
key_challenges.description: Fast, loose, rough and bumpy descent where gravel bikers slide out, photographers positioned to catch crashes

key_challenges.name: Silver Island pass descent
key_challenges.description: Fast and rowdy descent after aid station 1, riders almost lose control and go down

key_challenges.name: The big climb
key_challenges.description: Major climbing section near the end of the race in section four

terrain_notes.text: First gravel section is a bit bumpy and kind of fast but fun
Middle section feels like flying, averaging 17-19 mph on mountain bike on dirt

race_day_tips.text: Watch other riders' lines and see how hard they're pushing early in the race, heart rate management is critical
Don't push too hard in the first few miles - heart rate sitting at 150 is not sustainable for this race

additional_quotes.text: The race took us out through the silver Island Scenic back way and this was spectacular like it is so beautiful out there especially if you love rocks and mountains and you can see the mountains on your left and the Salt Flats on your right is just incredible

rider_intel.search_text: The Salty Lizard features a challenging early profile with a short but very steep road climb out of Wendover leading to the first gravel section. The course includes a notorious fast downhill section where gravel bikes slide out, followed by terrain that feels bumpy and fast. Aid station 1 sits at mile 17 near Silver Island pass, which features a fast and rowdy descent where riders nearly lose control. The middle section allows riders to fly at 17-19 mph on dirt through spectacular desert scenery with mountains on the left and Salt Flats on the right. The race splits at 65 and 100 mile options after the Silver Island descent. A major climbing challenge hits around mile 90 in the fourth section. Heart rate management proves critical as the early pace can spike unsustainably high. The course travels through the Silver Island Scenic back way offering beautiful desert mountain views.

Two cyclists riding gravel road through Silver Island Pass with desert mountains and sparse vegetation - Salty Lizard - Wendover, UT
Large peloton of gravel cyclists riding through Historic Wendover Airfield at sunset with hangar buildings visible - Salty Lizard - Wendover, UT
